description: TO TABLE THE RESOLUTION DIRECTING THE SECRETARY OF THE NAVY TO INFORM THE SENATE WHETHER THE FLAG OF THE PHILIPPINE REPUBLIC WAS CARRIED BY VESSELS IN THE BAY OF MANILA, AND IF IT WAS EVER SALUTED BY ADMIRAL DEWEY OR ANY VESSELS OF HIS FLEET AT ANY TIME INCE MAY 1, 1898.

TO AMEND S. 764, FIXING THE TIMES WHEN, REGULATING THE MAN- NER IN WHICH, AND DECLARING THE CHARACTER OF, THE ACCOUNTS BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND THE SEVERAL PUBLIC-LAND STATES RELATIVE TO THE NET PROCEEDS OF THE SALES AND OTHER DISPOS- ITION OF THE PBLIC-LANDS, AND CERTIFIED TO THE TREASURY DEPARTMENT FOR PAYMENT; WHICH AMENDMENT EXCLUDES ALL FORMER AND EXISTING INDIAN MILITARY, OR OTHER RESERVATIONS, IN ORDER TO SAVE THE GOVERNMENT FROM PAYING TO ANY STATE WHERE SAID RESERVATIONS ARE LOCATED, 5% OF ...

TO RECONSIDER THE RESOLUTION, RATIFIED 3/5/1900, (31 STAT. L. 1875) ADVISING AND CONSENTING TO THE CONVENTION BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES, GREAT BRITAIN AND GERMANY, TO ADJUST AMICABLY THE QUESTIONS BETWEEN THE THREE GOVERNMENTS IN RE- SPECT TO THE SAMOAN ROUP OF INLANDS

THAT THE SENATE RECEDE FROM ITS DISAGREEMENT TO THE HOUSE AMENDMENT BILL S. 2179 (31 STAT. 3, 2/1/1900), PROVIDING FOR TAKING OF THE TWELFTH AND SUBSEQUENT CENSUSES; IN ORDER TO AGREE TO AMENDMENT AUTHORIZING THE DIRECTOR OF THE CENSUS TO COLLECT STATISTCS RELATING TO THE DEAF, DUMB, AND BLIND

TO RECEDE FROM THE DISAGREEMENT TO HOUSE AMENDMENT TO BILL S. 2179 (31 STAT. 3, 2/1/1900), PROVIDING FOR THE TAKING OF THE TWELFTH AND SUBSEQUENT CENSUSES, IN ORDER TO AGREE TO AUTHORIZING AND DIRECTING THE DIRECTOR OF THE CENSUS TO COL- LECT STATISTICS N MINES, MINING AND MINERALS, AT THE SAME TIME THEY ARE COLLECTED ON POPULATIONS, AGRICULTURE, AND MANUFACTURES, SO AS TO SAVE TIME AND EXPENSE.

TO RATIFY THE CONVENTION BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES, GERMANY AND GREAT BRITAIN TO ADJUST AMICABLY THE QUESTIONS BETWEEN THE THREE GOVERNMENTS IN RESPECT TO THE SAMOAN GROUP OF ISLANDS, SIGNED AT WASHINGTON, D. C., DEC. 2, 1899.

TO REFER TO THE COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN RELATIONS, THE RESOLU- TION REQUESTING THE PRESIDENT TO INFORM THE SENATE WHETHER THE SAMOAN PEOPLE WERE CONSULTED RELATIVE TO THE TREATY BET- WEEN THE UNITED STATES AND GERMANY REGARDING SAMOA.  (P.1295 -1)

TO AMEND H. R. 1 (31 STAT. 45, 3/14/1900), A BILL DEFINING AND FIXING THE STANDARD OF VALUE TO MAINTAIN THE PARITY OF ALL FORMS OF MONEY ISSUED OR CARRIED BY THE UNITED STATES, BY GIVING THE PRESIDENT AUTHORITY TO APPOINT COMMISSIONS TO ANY INTERNATIONALCONFERENCE CALLED BY THE UNITED STATES, OR ANY OTHER COUNTRY, TO SECURE INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENT ON VALUE BETWEEN GOLD AND SILVER AS MONEY BY MEANS OF A COMMON RATIO BETWEEN THEM

TO AGREE TO A SUBSTITUTE FOR H. R. 1, WHICH STATES THAT THE PEOPLE OF THE UNITED STATES FAVORABLE TO BIMETALISM AND DESIROUS OF AN INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENT ADMITTING OF THE USE OF BOTH GOLD AND SILVER AT SUCH AN ESTABLISHED RATIO THAT WILL MAINTAIN PARITYBETWEEN GOLD AND SILVER COINS, AND THAT THE GOVERNMENT USE ITS EFFORTS TO SECURE THESE ENDS

TO AGREE TO THE AMENDMENT TO BILL H. R. 1, WHICH DECLARES THIS ACT IS NOT INTENDED TO OBSTRUCT INTERNATIONAL BIMETAL- LISM SECURED BY CONCURRENT ACTION OF THE LEADING COMMERCIAL NATIONS, AT A RATIO INSURING PERMANENCE OF RELATIVE VALUE BETWEEN GOLD AND SLVER

TO TABLE THE AMENDMENT TO H. R. 1, WHICH AMENDMENT PROPOSES TO MAKE THE NEW ISSUE OF TWO PER CENT UNITED STATES BONDS PAYABLE IN BOTH SILVER AND GOLD COIN OF THE VALUE OF THE ACT OF JULY 14, 1870.  (P.1829-1)

TO AMEND H. R. 1, BY PROVIDING THAT GOLD COINS AND SILVER DOLLARS COINED BY THE UNITED STATES SHALL BE LEGAL TENDER IN ALL PAYMENTS AT THEIR NOMINAL VALUE WHEN NOT BELOW THE WEIGHT AND LIMIT OF TOLERANCE, AND WHEN REDUCED IN WEIGHT BELOW STANDARD, SHALL E LEGAL TENDER AT VALUATION IN PRO- PORTION TO THEIR ACTUAL WEIGHT
TO AMEND H. R. 1, BY PROVIDING THAT NOTHING CONTAINED IN THIS ACT SHALL BE HELD OR CONSTRUED TO AFFECT THE PRESENT LEGAL TENDER QUALITY OF SILVER DOLLARS COINED BY THE UNITED STATES.  (P.1836-1)
TO AMEND H. R. 1, BY REPEALING ALL OTHER ACTS, OR PARTS OF ACTS, WHICH IMPOSE ANY TAX UPON THE CIRCULATION OF STATE BANKS OR STATE BANKING ASSOCIATIONS.  (P.1833-1)

TO AMEND H. R. 1, BY DECLARING IT IS THE FIXED POLICY OF THE UNITED STATES TO PAY AND CLEAR OFF THE NATIONAL DEBT AS RA- PIDLY AS JUST AND EQUAL TAXATION, AND THE ACCUMULATION OF OTHER GOVERNMENT REVENUE WILL PERMIT, AND THAT SPECIE BASED ON GOLD AND SILER IS THE ONLY TRUE BASIS ON WHICH TO ISSUE BANK BILLS CIRCULATING AS MONEY
TO AMEND H. R. 1, BY AUTHORIZING SILVER COINAGE AND THE COINING OF A SILVER DOLLAR OF 412 1/2 GRAINS TROY, OF STANDARD SILVER 9/10 FINE.  (P.1833-2)
TO PASS H. R. 1.
TO PROCEED TO THE CONSIDERATION OF S. RES. 107, BARRING MATTHEW S. QUAY FROM THE SENATE.

TO AMEND S. 222 (31 STAT. L. 141, 4/13/1900), PROVIDING A GOVERNMENT FOR THE TERRITORY OF HAWAII, BY ELIMINATING A RESTRICTION ON VOTERS IN THE TERRITORY WHICH WOULD REQUIRE POSSESSION IN THEIR OWN RIGHT OF REAL PROPERTY IN THE TERRITORY OF NOT LESS THANONE THOUSAND DOLLARS, OR AN IN- COME OF $600 FOR THE YEAR PROCEDING REGISTRATION
TO AGREE TO THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF CONFERENCE ON H. R. 1.  (P.2589-1)

L. 1939) BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND GREAT BRITAIN RELATING TO THE TENURE AND DISPOSITION OF REAL AND PERSONAL PROPERTY, SIGNED MARCH 2, 1899, BY ELIMINATING FROM ARTICLE FOUR THE PROVI- SION THAT THE UEEN CAN GIVE NOTICE OF ADHESION ON BEHALF OF ANY BRITISH PROTECTORATE OR SPHERE OF INFLUENCE OR ON BEHALF OF THE ISLAND OF CYPRESS IN VIRTUE OF THE CONVENTION OF JUNE 4, 1878, BETWEEN GREAT BRITAIN AND TURKEY.
TO AMEND THE TREATY BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND GREAT BRITAIN ELIMINATING THEREFROM THE FIFTH ARTICLE.
TO RATIFY THE TREATY BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND GREAT BRITAIN.

R. 8245 (31 STAT. 77, 4/12/1900), TEMPOR- ARILY PROVIDING REVENUES FOR THE RELIEF OF THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO; BY PROPOSING THAT ANY CITIZEN DEPOSITING FOR COINAGE AT ANY UNITED STATES MINT, SILVER BULLION OF NOT LESS THAN $100, ESTIMATD AT 371 1/4 GRAIN OF PURE SILVER PER DOLLAR AND AT SAME TIME AS PART OF SAME, DEPOSITS OF GOLD BULLION OF EQUAL OR GREATER AMOUNT AT RATE OF 23 AND 22 1/160 GRAINS OF PURE GOLD PER DOLLAR, SHALL BE ENTITLED TO HAVE SAME COINED IN UNITED STATES COINS, IN ...

TO AMEND S. 3419 (31 STAT. L. 321, 6/6/1900), BY MAKING IT THE DUTY OF THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR TO DECLARE AND PUBLISH PROPER RULES AND REGULATIONS WHEREBY THE AURIFEROUS DEPOSITS IN ALASKA WHICH LIE BELOW THE LOW-WATER MARK OF THE OCEAN AND ITS TRIUTARIES SHALL, IF FEASIBLE, BE OPEN TO EX- PLORATION BY ANY UNITED STATES CITIZEN AND GIVING THE SECRE- TARY OF WAR POWER TO POLICE THE SOIL AND FULFILL THE OBLIGA- TIONS HE OWES UNDER LAW TO DREDGE AND EXCAVATE CANELS

TO AMEND H. R. 8245, BY PROPOSING THAT ANY CITIZEN DEPOSTING FOR COINAGE AT ANY UNITED STATES MINT, SILVER BULLION OF NOT LESS THAN $100, ESTIMATED AT 371 1/4 GRAINS OF PURE SILVER PER DOLLAR AND AT THE SAME TIME, AS PART OF SAME, DEPOSITS GOLD BULLION O EQUAL OR GREATER AMOUNT AT RATE OF 23 AND 22 1/160 GRAINS OF PURE GOLD PER DOLLAR, SHALL BE ENTITLED TO HAVE SOME COINED IN UNITED STATES COINS IN LAWFUL DEMON- INATIONS
TO AMEND BILL H. R. 8245, BY ELIMINATING TAX LEVIED ON COFFEE IN THE BEAN OR GROUND, IMPORTED INTO PUERTO RICO. (P.3469-1)

TO AMEND H. R. 8245, BY ELIMINATING THE SECTION PROPOSING TO LEVY A DUTY ON ALL MERCHANDISE IMPORTED AND EXPORTED BET- WEEN THE UNITED STATES AND PUERTO RICO, THE DUTY TO BE 15% OF LIKE MERCHANDISE IMPORTED FROM FOREIGN COUNTRIES. (P.3474-1)
TO CONSENT TO THE APPOINTMENT OF WILLIAM D. BYNUM AS GENERAL APPRAISER OF MERCHANDISE.  (P.443, 232-412)

TO AMEND BILL H. R. 8245, BY MAKING ONE PUERTO RICAN PESO WORTH 93 1/2 INSTEAD OF 60, THEREBY MORE QUICKLY REPLACING  S5 PUERTO RICAN COINS WITH UNITED STATES COINS AND ALSO REDEEM- ING THE PUERTO RICAN COINS ON A MORE EQUITABLE VALUE IN ACCORDANCE WITH HEIR SILVER CONTENT
TO AMEND H. R. 8245, BY EXTENDING TO PUERTO RICO THE CONSTI- TUTION AND LAWS OF THE UNITED STATES WITH THE SAME FORCE AND EFFECT AS IN OTHER UNITED STATES TERRITORIES.  (P.3513-2)
TO AMEND BILL H. R. 8245, BY PROHIBITING THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF PUERTO RICO FROM ENACTING ANY LAW CONFLICTING WITH THE UNITED STATES CONSTITUTION.  (P.3563-2)

TO AMEND H. R. 8245, BY MAKING PUERTO RICO AN INTERNAL REVENUE DISTRICT IN WHICH THE LAWS OF THE UNITED STATES SHALL CONTINUE IN FORCE, AND BY HAVING THE PRESIDENT, WITH SENATE ADVICE AND CONSENT, APPOINT A COLLECTOR OF REVENUE AT A SALARY OF $4,000 PER NNUM, WHO SHALL COLLECT TAXES WHICH SHALL BE EXPENDED UNDER PRESIDENTIAL DIRECTION, FOR THE GOVERNMENT OF PURETO RICO

TO AMEND H. R. 8245, BY EXEMPTING FROM DUTY ALL ARTICLES IMPORTED INTO THE UNITED STATES FROM PUERTO RICO, AND INTO PUERTO RICO FROM THE UNITED STATES, BY MAKING ARTICLES FROM PUERTO RICO SUBJECT TO UNITED STATES INTERNAL REVENUE TAXES EQUAL TO THOSE PAI IN THE UNITED STATES
TO PASS H. R. 8245, WHICH WAS REPORTED BY THE COMMITTEE ON THE PACIFIC ISLANDS AND PUERTO RICO.

TO ADJOURN, MOTION MADE DURING CONSIDERATION OF S. 2355, RE- LATING TO THE SUPPRESSION OF INSURRECTION IN THE PHILIPPINES AND TO THE GOVERNMENT OF THE PHILIPPINES, CEDED BY SPAIN ON DECEMBER 10, 1898.  (P.3698-1)

TO AMEND H. R. 7433 (31 STAT. 221, 5/3/1900), PERMITTING THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR TO MAKE CONTRACTS WITH THE PRESENT CONTRACT SCHOOLS FOR EDUCATING INDIAN PUPILS DURING THE FIS- CAL YEAR 1901, BUT ONLY WHERE GOVERNMENT SCHOOLS ARE NOT PROVIDED.

TO AMEND S. 2, PROVIDING FOR THE CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION OF A PACIFIC CABLE UNDER MANAGEMENT OF THE NAVY DEPARTMENT BY ELIMINATING SECTION 5, WHICH PROVIDES FOR THE USE OF AMERICAN MATERIALS IN BUILDING THE CABLE, IF PROCURABLE AT NO MORETHAN 12% ABOVE COST OF FOREIGN MATER- IALS
TO POSTPONE CONSIDERATION OF S. 2355, IN ORDER TO TAKE UP BILL S. 1783, PROVIDING FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF AN INTER- OCEANIC CANAL CONNECTING THE WATERS OF THE ATLANTIC AND PACIFIC OCEANS.  (P.4094-2)

TO AMEND S. 3419 (31 STAT. L, 321, 6/6/1900), MAKING FURTHER PROVISIONS FOR A CIVIL GOVERNMENT FOR ALASKA, BY DECLARING IT IS INTENDED THAT LOCATIONS UPON, CLAIMS TO, LANDS WITHIN SAID RESERVATIONS SHALL HAVE ORIGINATED ONLY AFTER PASSAGE AND TAKING EFFET OF THIS ACT, BUT SAID RESERVATION OF A ROADWAY SIXTY FEET WIDE SHALL NOT APPLY TO MINERAL LANDS OR TOWN SITES
TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION DENYING MATTHEW S. QUAY HIS SEAT AS A SENATOR FROM PENNSYLVANIA, BY GRANTING HIM HIS SEAT. (P.4612-2)

TO REFER TO THE COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN RELATIONS, S. RES. 133, THE PROPOSAL THAT WE MATCH WITH DEEP AND ABIDING INTEREST THE HEROIC BATTLE OF THE SOUTH AFRICAN REPUBLIC AGAINST CRUELTY AND OPPRESSION, AND THAT OUR BEST HOPES GO OUT FOR THE FULL SUCCESS OF HEIR DETERMINED CONTEST FOR LIBERTY, NO QUORUM VOTING.
TO PROCEED TO THE CONSIDERATION OF S. RES. 133, SUPRESSING THE HOPE FOR THE SUCCESS OF THE SOUTH AFRICAN REPUBLIC IN THEIR DETERMINED CONTEST FOR LIBERTY.  (P.4831-2)

TO AMEND BILL S. 4300, BY PROVIDING FOR A VETERINARY CORPS CONSISTING OF A CHIEF VETERINARIAN, WITH THE RANK AND PAY OF COLONEL; AN ASSISTANT CHIEF WITH THE RANK AND PAY OF MAJOR; FOUR ASSISTANTS WITH THE RANK AND PAY OF CAPTAIN OF CAVALRY; TEN ASSISTANT WITH THE RANK AND PAY OF FIRST-LIEU- TENANT OF CAVALRY AND TWENTY ASSISTANTS WITH THE RANK AND PAY OF SECOND-LIEUTENANT OF CAVALRY; TO BE UNDER REGULATIONS MADE BY THE SECRETARY OF WAR, THUS ABOLISHING THE HIRING OF UNRESPONSIBLE CIVILIANS

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO H. R. 10450 (31 STAT. L. 684, 6/7/1900), AMENDING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE NAVAL SERVICE FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1901, BY PROVIDING THAT FROM AND AFTER PASSAGE OF THIS ACT, NO FURTHER ORIGINAL APPOINT- MENTS OF OFFICERS EXCEPT TO FILL VACANCIES IN THE NUMBER THEN EXISTING IN MARINE CORPS SHALL BE MADE WITHOUT FURTHER AUTHORITY FROM CONGRESS AND NO FURTHER ENLISTMENTS IN MARINE CORPS
